Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Abundance, trophic transfer, and cross-ecosystem movement of multiple cyanotoxins in arctic lakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Freshwater lakes provide critical value human populations, from water supply for households, industry, and agriculture to opportunities for active and passive recreation. However, lake-dwelling cyanobacteria and their toxins, cyanotoxins, are of increasing concern, threatening the health of aquatic food webs and the safe uses of freshwaters. Most studies of cyanotoxins have focused on temperate and tropical systems with conspicuous surface blooms of planktonic cyanobacteria. However, not all toxin-producing cyanobacteria form surface blooms, both bottom-dwelling cyanobacteria and very small single cells in the water column, can produce toxins, and the abundance, impacts on organisms that consume the cyanobacteria, and the potential for toxins to move from lakes to the lands surrounding them is poorly understood, especially in polar regions. To date, very few studies have examined whether polar freshwater cyanobacteria produce cyanotoxins and the extent to which cyanotoxins move through polar aquatic food webs or into terrestrial ecosystems remains largely unknown. This project will expand our understanding of the types of ecosystems that support toxic cyanobacteria and contribute to the evaluation of which systems are currently at risk or may become at risk in the future. Studies of the cyanotoxins produced by both bottom-dwelling cyanobacteria and very small single cells in the water column will take place in lakes and ponds in Greenland. To complement ongoing studies of the most common class of cyanotoxin, the researchers will evaluate the production of four additional toxins and their transfer through aquatic food webs and into terrestrial ecosystems. As such, this project will expand the knowledge on the geographic and taxonomic range and ecological distribution of cyanotoxins relevant in both the scientific and public health communities.

The research funded by this grant will use samples previously collected from 19 lakes and ponds in southwestern Greenland to (1) quantify the abundance of four additional classes of cyanotoxins (anatoxin-a, saxitoxins, cylindrospermosins, and BMAA) within the aquatic ecosystem and (2) estimate cyanotoxin transfer to terrestrial ecosystems in order to obtain a more complete picture of within- and across-ecosystem movement of biotoxins in Arctic lakes and nearby terrestrial habitats. Preliminary data suggest that hepatoxic microcystins are produced and released by benthic colonial cyanobacteria of the genus Nostoc and are also found in pelagic non-blooming phytoplankton. Moreover, microcystins are being transferred into zooplankton and invertebrate larvae. This research will extend these microcystin analyses into the terrestrial environment and investigate the presence of four additional cyanotoxins within the food web. The researchers will investigate toxin production, the transfer of cyanotoxins to other organisms in the lake, and several mechanisms (i.e., emerging insects, aerosols) that may influence the movement of toxins from the aquatic to terrestrial ecosystem. The already-documented presence and movement of cyanotoxins in these lakes demonstrate that high-latitude lakes can support toxigenic cyanobacteria, and that we may be underestimating the potential for these systems to develop high levels of toxicity in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Lake-dwelling cyanobacteria and their toxins are of increasing ecological and economic concern worldwide, threatening the health of aquatic food webs and the safe use of freshwater by humans. Very little is currently known about the presence and trophic transfer of cyanotoxins in lakes that lack conspicuous surface blooms, especially at high latitudes. Our objectives were to (1) test for the presence of the widespread cyanotoxin microcystin (MC) in the water and key taxa within Greenlandic lake and land food webs and (2) evaluate the potential for toxin transfer within a lake, and from lakes to land. Using samples collected from lakes in Kangerlussuaq, Greenland over multiple summers, we quantified the concentrations of MC in whole lake water, aquatic food web components, plant material from nearshore and upland zones surrounding each lake, emerging insects, and terrestrial invertebrates. Additionally, through collaboration with Dr. Árni Einarsson and Dr. Claudio Gratton of the Mývatn LTREB project (NSF DEB 1556208), we compared our findings for MC levels in Greenlandic food webs to those in Lake Mývatn, Iceland, a subarctic system known to contain pelagic cyanobacteria (genus Dolichospermum) and renowned for its large annual emergence of midges, which transfer nutrients from the lake to the surrounding landscape.

Findings

Our study revealed for the first time that MC is present in six different functional groups from Greenlandic lake food webs, with highest concentrations in large (>50 µm) phytoplankton, followed by zooplankton, benthic (bottom-dwelling) colonial cyanobacteria (genus Nostoc), chironomid larvae, dytiscid larvae, and snails. These findings indicate that while MC are transferred within the aquatic food web, concentrations are lower in consumers than in their prey items – i.e., MC does not bioaccumulate.  Similarly, we detected MC in aquatic taxa from Lake Mývatn, with pelagic cyanobacteria containing the highest concentrations, followed by zooplankton, blackfly larvae, fish, and benthic macroalgae. We also found MC in sediment from Mývatn, which indicates that sediment may be an additional benthic source of cyanotoxins in aquatic environments.

In the terrestrial food web, we measured detectable levels of MC in adult midges that emerged from both Greenland lakes and Lake Mývatn, suggesting that emerging insects represent a non-trophic pathway for toxin transfer from water to land during their transition from an aquatic larval life stage to a terrestrial adult life stage. We also detected MC in spiders, caterpillars, and mosquitos from Greenland, suggesting that cyanotoxins can also be transferred from aquatic to terrestrial food webs through trophic pathways. Finally, we also detected low levels of MC (near the detection limit of our assay) in shrubs, sedges, and mosses surrounding nine of the Greenlandic lakes in our study.

Taken together, our results demonstrate the presence of cyanotoxins in Arctic lake ecosystems despite the absence of surface bloom-forming cyanobacteria and indicate that both benthic and pelagic cyanobacteria represent potential sources of cyanotoxins into aquatic food webs. Our findings also suggest that cyanotoxins can be transferred across aquatic-terrestrial boundaries and that there are likely multiple mechanisms of transfer. Finally, our comparative analyses of Greenlandic lakes with Lake Mývatn, Iceland, suggest that the transfer of MC in aquatic foods (1) can occur in systems dominated by either pelagic cyanobacteria (i.e., Lake Mývatn) or benthic cyanobacteria (i.e., Greenlandic lakes), and (2) may be more widespread in Arctic and subarctic regions than previously recognized.

Training and Development

This project provided important experience for co-PI Trout-Haney in research and grants management, as well as significant technical training for three undergraduate students who assisted in processing, extraction and analysis of toxin samples. The research team made three presentations of these results at national and international scientific conferences, published two peer-reviewed publications, and has three additional publications in development.
